hooks.name: Auto Formatter
hooks.description: Automatically formats code files after edits using prettier or language-specific formatters
hooks.longDescription: This hook runs automatically after Claude edits any code file. It detects the file type and applies the appropriate formatter (prettier for .ts/.js/.tsx, gofmt for .go, etc.). This ensures consistent code style across your project without manual intervention. The hook intelligently detects file extensions and applies the right formatting tool, making code reviews smoother and maintaining high code quality standards.
hooks.author: ChrisWiles
hooks.example:
#!/bin/bash
# format.sh
if [[ $TOOL_INPUT =~ \.ts$ ]]; then
  npx prettier --write "$TOOL_INPUT"
elif [[ $TOOL_INPUT =~ \.go$ ]]; then
  gofmt -w "$TOOL_INPUT"
fi

hooks.name: Production File Protection
hooks.description: Blocks modifications to production files and sensitive directories to prevent accidental changes
hooks.longDescription: This security hook intercepts permission requests and blocks Claude from modifying files in production directories, configuration files, or any paths you designate as sensitive. It provides an essential safety layer when working with Claude Code in production environments or repositories with critical infrastructure code. The hook returns a clear error message explaining why the modification was blocked, helping maintain system integrity.
hooks.author: Community
hooks.example:
#!/bin/bash
# check-permissions.sh
if [[ "$TOOL_INPUT" =~ /prod/|/config/secrets ]]; then
  echo '{"continue": false, "systemMessage": "Access denied: Cannot modify production files"}'
  exit 2
fi
exit 0

hooks.name: Command Logger
hooks.description: Logs all Claude Code tool executions for auditing, debugging, and compliance tracking
hooks.longDescription: This monitoring hook captures every tool execution Claude Code performs, creating a detailed audit trail. It logs the tool name, input parameters, timestamp, and session context to a file or external logging service. Perfect for teams that need compliance documentation, debugging assistance, or want to analyze Claude's decision patterns. The logs can be configured to include different verbosity levels and can integrate with existing logging infrastructure.
hooks.author: disler
hooks.example:
#!/bin/bash
# log-command.sh
TIMESTAMP=$(date -u +"%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ")
echo "[$TIMESTAMP] Tool: $TOOL_NAME | Input: $TOOL_INPUT" >> ~/claude-audit.log
exit 0

hooks.name: Desktop Notifications
hooks.description: Sends desktop notifications when Claude Code needs user input or completes long-running tasks
hooks.longDescription: This notification hook uses native OS notification systems to alert you when Claude Code requires your attention. Whether you're working in another application or stepped away from your desk, you'll get notified when Claude completes a task, encounters an error, or needs your input. Supports macOS notification center, Linux notify-send, and Windows toast notifications. Customize notification titles, messages, and urgency levels based on the event type.
hooks.author: Community
hooks.example:
#!/bin/bash
# notify.sh (macOS)
osascript -e 'display notification "Claude Code needs your input" with title "Claude Code"'
# Linux alternative:
# notify-send "Claude Code" "Needs your input"

hooks.name: Code Convention Checker
hooks.description: Validates code against project-specific naming conventions and style guidelines after edits
hooks.longDescription: This code quality hook analyzes edited files against your project's coding standards and naming conventions. It checks for proper variable naming (camelCase, PascalCase, snake_case), file naming patterns, function length limits, and custom regex patterns you define. When violations are detected, Claude receives feedback about what needs to be fixed, allowing it to automatically correct the code. Integrates with ESLint, Pylint, or custom validation scripts.
hooks.author: Community
hooks.example:
#!/bin/bash
# check-conventions.sh
if grep -q "var " "$TOOL_INPUT"; then
  echo '{"continue": false, "systemMessage": "Use const/let instead of var"}'
  exit 2
fi
exit 0

hooks.name: Automatic Test Runner
hooks.description: Automatically runs relevant tests after code changes to catch regressions early
hooks.longDescription: This automation hook triggers test execution whenever Claude modifies code files. It intelligently runs only the tests related to changed files, providing fast feedback on whether the changes break existing functionality. Supports Jest, Pytest, Go test, and other popular testing frameworks. The hook can be configured to run unit tests only for speed, or include integration tests for thorough validation. Test results are fed back to Claude so it can fix failures automatically.
hooks.author: Community
hooks.example:
#!/bin/bash
# run-tests.sh
if [[ "$TOOL_INPUT" =~ \.test\.(ts|js)$ ]]; then
  npm test -- "$TOOL_INPUT"
elif [[ "$TOOL_INPUT" =~ \.py$ ]]; then
  pytest "$TOOL_INPUT"
fi

hooks.name: Git Commit Message Assistant
hooks.description: Generates semantic commit messages based on code changes following conventional commits
hooks.longDescription: This automation hook analyzes git diffs and suggests properly formatted commit messages following the Conventional Commits specification. It categorizes changes as feat, fix, docs, refactor, test, etc., and generates concise, informative commit messages. The hook can automatically stage changes and create commits, or just suggest messages for manual review. Integrates with git hooks and supports custom commit message templates for your team's workflow.
hooks.author: Community
hooks.example:
# This is a prompt-based hook
# Claude will analyze changes and suggest commits like:
# feat: add user authentication
# fix: resolve null pointer in login handler
# docs: update API documentation

hooks.name: Dependency Security Scanner
hooks.description: Scans package files for known vulnerabilities when dependencies are added or updated
hooks.longDescription: This security hook automatically scans package.json, requirements.txt, go.mod, and other dependency files for known security vulnerabilities whenever they're modified. It uses vulnerability databases like npm audit, pip-audit, or Snyk to check for CVEs and security advisories. When vulnerabilities are found, Claude receives detailed information about the risk level, affected versions, and available patches, allowing it to automatically update to secure versions or warn you about the risks.
hooks.author: Community
hooks.example:
#!/bin/bash
# scan-deps.sh
if [[ "$TOOL_INPUT" =~ package\.json$ ]]; then
  npm audit --json
elif [[ "$TOOL_INPUT" =~ requirements\.txt$ ]]; then
  pip-audit -r "$TOOL_INPUT"
fi

hooks.name: Performance Profiler
hooks.description: Profiles code execution and reports performance metrics after changes to critical paths
hooks.longDescription: This monitoring hook runs performance benchmarks on modified code to detect performance regressions. It measures execution time, memory usage, and CPU utilization for critical code paths. The hook compares current metrics against baseline performance data and alerts when changes cause significant slowdowns. Supports various profiling tools like Python's cProfile, Go's pprof, Node.js profilers, and custom benchmarking scripts. Results are visualized and fed back to Claude for optimization suggestions.
hooks.author: Community
hooks.example:
#!/bin/bash
# profile.sh
if [[ "$TOOL_INPUT" =~ \.py$ ]]; then
  python -m cProfile -o profile.stats "$TOOL_INPUT"
  python -c "import pstats; p=pstats.Stats('profile.stats'); p.print_stats(10)"
fi

hooks.name: Auto Documentation Generator
hooks.description: Automatically generates or updates documentation when code changes using AI
hooks.longDescription: This automation hook uses Claude's capabilities to generate comprehensive documentation for code changes. When you modify functions, classes, or APIs, the hook analyzes the changes and updates corresponding documentation files, README sections, or API docs. It can generate JSDoc comments, Python docstrings, inline code comments, and markdown documentation. The hook ensures documentation stays in sync with code, reducing technical debt and improving maintainability.
hooks.author: Community
hooks.example:
# This is a prompt-based hook
# Claude will generate documentation like:
/**
 * Calculates the total price including tax
 * @param price - Base price before tax
 * @param taxRate - Tax rate as decimal (e.g. 0.1 for 10%)
 * @returns Total price with tax applied
 */

hooks.name: Code Complexity Analyzer
hooks.description: Analyzes cyclomatic complexity and warns about overly complex code that needs refactoring
hooks.longDescription: This code quality hook calculates cyclomatic complexity, cognitive complexity, and other code metrics for modified files. It identifies functions or methods that exceed complexity thresholds, making them hard to test and maintain. The hook provides specific feedback about which parts of the code are too complex and suggests refactoring strategies. Integrates with tools like radon (Python), gocyclo (Go), and complexity-report (JavaScript) to provide language-specific analysis.
hooks.author: Community
hooks.example:
#!/bin/bash
# check-complexity.sh
if [[ "$TOOL_INPUT" =~ \.py$ ]]; then
  radon cc "$TOOL_INPUT" -a -nb
elif [[ "$TOOL_INPUT" =~ \.js$ ]]; then
  npx complexity-report "$TOOL_INPUT"
fi

hooks.name: Session Summary Logger
hooks.description: Creates a detailed summary of work completed when Claude Code session ends
hooks.longDescription: This logging hook runs at the end of each Claude Code session and generates a comprehensive summary of all work performed. It lists files modified, tests run, commits created, and tasks completed during the session. The summary is saved to a markdown file with timestamps and can be automatically added to daily work logs, project wikis, or sent to team collaboration tools like Slack. Perfect for stand-ups, progress tracking, and project management.
hooks.author: Community
hooks.example:
#!/bin/bash
# session-summary.sh
DATE=$(date +%Y-%m-%d)
echo "# Claude Code Session - $DATE" > ~/work-logs/session-$DATE.md
echo "Session ID: $SESSION_ID" >> ~/work-logs/session-$DATE.md
git log --oneline --since="1 hour ago" >> ~/work-logs/session-$DATE.md

hooks.name: AI Code Reviewer
hooks.description: Performs AI-powered code review checking for bugs, anti-patterns, and improvement opportunities
hooks.longDescription: This code quality hook uses Claude's analysis capabilities to perform thorough code reviews on modified files. It checks for common bugs, security vulnerabilities, performance issues, code smells, and violations of best practices. The hook provides detailed feedback with specific line numbers and suggested improvements, similar to a human code reviewer. It can identify issues like SQL injection risks, race conditions, memory leaks, and logical errors that traditional linters might miss.
hooks.author: Community
hooks.example:
# This is a prompt-based hook
# Claude will analyze code and provide feedback like:
# - Line 42: Potential SQL injection vulnerability
# - Line 57: Resource not closed, may cause memory leak
# - Line 89: Consider using const instead of let

hooks.name: Environment Validator
hooks.description: Validates environment configuration and detects missing or incorrect environment variables
hooks.longDescription: This security and automation hook checks .env files, docker-compose configurations, and other environment setups for completeness and correctness. It validates that required environment variables are present, values match expected formats (URLs, ports, booleans), and no sensitive data is accidentally committed. The hook can compare against .env.example templates, check for common misconfigurations, and ensure development/staging/production environments are properly configured.
hooks.author: Community
hooks.example:
#!/bin/bash
# validate-env.sh
if [[ "$TOOL_INPUT" =~ \.env ]]; then
  # Check for required variables
  required=("DATABASE_URL" "API_KEY" "PORT")
  for var in "${required[@]}"; do
    if ! grep -q "^$var=" "$TOOL_INPUT"; then
      echo "Missing required variable: $var"
      exit 2
    fi
  done
fi

hooks.name: Build Validator
hooks.description: Runs build process after code changes to catch compilation and bundling errors early
hooks.longDescription: This automation hook triggers your project's build process whenever code is modified, ensuring changes don't break the build. It runs TypeScript compilation, webpack bundling, or other build steps and reports errors immediately. The hook can be configured to run full builds or incremental builds for speed. Build errors are fed back to Claude with specific file locations and error messages, enabling automatic fixes. Essential for maintaining a healthy codebase in TypeScript, React, and other compiled languages.
hooks.author: Community
